1093380725405999104.text: Blockchain is an anti-monopoly technology, whether the monopoly arises from state licensing, network effects, or other forms of concentrated power. By incentivizing decentralization, the profit-maximizing equilibria is no longer fully centralized. There is always an exit.

1093377666260951045.text: Blockchains aren’t about trusting no one. They are about giving you a choice of who to trust. The addition of that choice — the ability to exit from monopoly institutions that previously had no alternative, like banks — unlocks value that justifies all the technical complexity.

1051204719023087616.text: Essentially, the “double send” problem is not just a technical problem but also a UX problem and there are a few different solutions. Good to collect ideas!

1051203333896032256.text: Note that (a) an on-chain tx is not “just” a digital signature and (b) an on-chain transaction need not be visible to everyone to work. You could use Zcash-style viewing keys. Or you could take a parallel approach via ENS-style legible addresses. Or perhaps solve via wallet UX.

1051201956817993728.text: Yes, you might use just a digital signature — or maybe an on-chain $0 tx of some kind. The empirical user behavior right now is to use a block explorer to see if small funds were truly received on-chain before sending large funds. A fix may have to be visible on-chain to work.https://twitter.com/gakonst/status/1051086560614076422 …

1050984220376457216.text: The $0 send could be implemented in different blockchains in different ways via various message signing schemes, or perhaps even via zero knowledge proofs. If the UX was modified appropriately, it could be a way to confirm the receiving address was correct before moving money.

1050982970306121728.text: We should figure out UX and/or technical conventions to solve it. One idea could be a “$0 send” which would mean proving to the receiving address that you controlled the private keys of the sending address without actually sending any money from that address.

1050982014784946177.text: This is the “double send” problem. Basically, for any large send of crypto, people first send a small amount once to confirm receipt and then a large amount a second time. That double send reduces privacy due to address reuse.https://twitter.com/twobitidiot/status/1050765950692315137 …

1049420482313826304.text: While 33 bits is full deanonymization, partial deanonymization is also a risk under some scenarios. For example, 28 bits would get you down to a subset of ~20-30 people. That’s often too close for comfort. Privacy is thus a continuum, not a switch.

1049419164450873344.text: Targeting is not an all or nothing thing. @random_walker has a useful frame on this problem with his concept of 33 bits. Because 2^33 is greater than ~7B, you need 33 bits to fully deanonymize someone in a (conceptual) database table of all ~7B people worldwide.

1049377749817651200.text: This tweet encapsulates how commercially valuable trust is. Here, the trust that Apple is not incentivized to eavesdrop (even if they are in theory capable of it) is a significant competitive advantage.https://twitter.com/tomfgoodwin/status/1049309162792865792 …

1049376416930783232.text: Now, obviously, most end users aren’t tech savvy enough to do that. And even those that are wouldn’t usually want to take the trouble. But the mere fact that it *could* be done and that the backend was open source would bolster confidence. No longer a black box. Exit is feasible.

1049375723369029633.text: How might an end user audit the end-to-end encryption of a messaging app? Maybe the most trustworthy option would be to provide an open source backend implementation like Signal. If any end user pair could (optionally!) put their own server in the middle, it would increase trust.

1042847541304279041.text: Complement not substitute. Cryptography is an external mechanism that establishes mathematically provable scarcity of various kinds (from money supply via hard caps to liquidity via timelocks), which is complementary to shared human belief. Belief is necessary but not sufficient.

1042846729920376837.text: @mattyglesias @TheStalwart If you are interested in how timelocks work, it’s completely opt in. Like an IPO lockup or a vesting schedule, but cryptographically provable. It shows commitment to the long haul. https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Timelock

1042845979693613056.text: No, capital controls are involuntarily imposed. Timelocking your crypto is like agreeing to a vesting schedule or lockup terms. It signals long-term commitment to attract other long-term investors.https://twitter.com/TheStalwart/status/1042744490040217602 …

1042696403896557568.text: A social network is valuable if it has many monthly active users. A crypto project is valuable if it has large amounts of monthly *inactive* hodling. And timelocks are the ultimate hodl. So, the more that is publicly & provably timelocked, the more valuable the remaining coins.

1042294999356891137.text: Btw, to combine rapid user acquisition and monetization, it’s worth building blockchain-based social networks. The key could be to put just the right data on the blockchain (perhaps just user balances), to avoid trying to decentralize the whole thing at once.

1042292166704357376.text: Anyway, the next big thing never looks quite like the last. Crypto will eventually go from tens of millions to billions of users. But the path there — and the relevant metrics — will be quite different from the past decade of tech.

1042289783676919809.text: In the blockchain space, people might argue about the quality of monetization but they wouldn’t argue with the quantity. The main q is whether crypto can become something people use on a regular basis. But good projects already have millions of MAUs: https://brave.com/brave-passes-3-million-monthly-active-users/ …

1042288626447470592.text: No one ever doubted that social networks could attract huge numbers of daily active users. They just doubted that they could turn that into money. And the doubts continued for years, even till 2013! https://qz.com/49528/why-facebook-will-never-make-a-significant-profit/ …pic.twitter.com/yHRDbBcdZQ

1042286751639732224.text: Crypto is evolving differently from social. Social networks acquired users easily but had to prove monetization over time. Crypto projects can monetize easily but must prove user acquisition over time.
